channel.title: RS2 Updater
channel.description:
Updated this since im not done with version tracker (the new version of this)
I made this update all files that the loader downloads including the loader and fixed a few minor problems.
Added batches for service running also.
All of the info for the usage of this as a service on windows can be found in the "win-service-setup" folder.
to run it you can use run.bat or setup your own system
source is included in src/
The rest is pretty much self explanitory...

item.title: RS2 Updater
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

HEY IDIOTS THEY STRIP THE MAGIC NUMBER SO THAT ANYBODY LOOKING AT THE FILE WILL HAVE A HARD TIME FIGURING OUT WHAT IT IS

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:27, topic:299689”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=395982.msg2943406#msg2943406 date=1252058146]
probably because they are the same client now
[/quote]

Looks like loader.jar and loader_gl.jar are the same file now, I can’t say about the runescape.jar and runescape_gl.pack200 because they are different formats, but the jar spit out by my pack200tojar is not the same as the runescape.jar.[/quote]runescape.jar is for unsigned

item.title: RS2 Updater
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:23, topic:299689”][quote author=Killer-99-pkz link=topic=395982.msg2942714#msg2942714 date=1252008481]
Please point out things that you think is rong with my code…
[/quote]

I haven’t looked at the actual code either, but I’ve already said a few areas in which it could be improved. The only way to tell if jagex has released a new file (not new version, new file) is to download it and see if it is the same, a hash does this well, in java you could use crc32 or something. Also, check every X amount of time (like I said, I check every hour). And add the ability to add more files to the check and such.[/quote]i was just thinking randomly, as i do… you could download the loader, it contains a class with instances of a class that contains information on the files that it loads

this is from some older version of the loader

[code]public class a
{

public static g a = new g("game_unpacker.dat", "unpackclass_-1911426584.pack", new String[] {
    "Loading unpacker", "Lade Entpacker", "D\351compression", "Carregando descompactador", "Uitpakprogramma wordt geladen"
}, 19788, 19788, new int[] {
    -3, -104, -67, 100, 126, -102, -46, -103, -8, 46, 
    84, -115, 18, -18, 41, -18, 1, 118, -121, 89
});
public static g b = new g("main_file_cache.dat3", "runescape_805829668.pack200", new String[] {
    "Loading game code", "Lade Spiel-Code", "Chargement du code du jeu", "Carregando c\363digo do jogo", "Gamecode wordt geladen"
}, 0x8bbd9, 0x8bbd9, new int[] {
    -40, 20, -84, 54, -112, 40, -111, -18, -101, 107, 
    -25, 84, -62, 118, 26, 77, -123, -54, 77, 97
});
public static g c = new g("main_file_cache.dat4", "runescape_-1832102248.js5", new String[] {
    "Loading game code", "Lade Spiel-Code", "Chargement du code du jeu", "Carregando c\363digo do jogo", "Gamecode wordt geladen"
}, 0x8cdc1, 0x8cdc1, new int[] {
    -57, 76, -114, -85, -69, 40, 91, -111, -7, 82, 
    37, 15, 43, -15, -70, -60, -104, 68, 85, -35
});
public static g d[][] = {
    {
        new g("jaggl.dll", "jaggl_0_0_-1855459239.lib", new String[] {
            "Loading 3D library", "Lade 3D-Softwarebibliothek", "Chargement de la librairie 3D", "Carregando biblioteca 3D", "Loading 3D library"
        }, 0x14000, 32536, new int[] {
            -55, -64, -96, 38, -87, -122, 35, -120, 48, -69, 
            -126, -57, 53, 80, 60, 62, -39, -2, 20, -78
        })
    }, {
        new g("libjaggl.so", "jaggl_1_0_232191354.lib", new String[] {
            "Loading 3D library (1/2)", "Lade 3D-Softwarebibliothek (1/2)", "Chargement de la librairie 3D (1/2)", "Carregando biblioteca 3D (1/2)", "Loading 3D library (1/2)"
        }, 0x12248, 18288, new int[] {
            -50, 63, 74, 47, 127, -96, -110, -90, 55, 30, 
            -80, -38, -63, -8, -83, 32, 65, 126, -78, -57
        }), new g("libjaggl_dri.so", "jaggl_1_1_1808963541.lib", new String[] {
            "Loading 3D library (2/2)", "Lade 3D-Softwarebibliothek (2/2)", "Chargement de la librairie 3D (2/2)", "Carregando biblioteca 3D (2/2)", "Loading 3D library (2/2)"
        }, 3364, 1566, new int[] {
            -58, 89, 68, 25, -5, 48, -122, -105, 113, -86, 
            58, -127, 58, 74, 47, -75, 23, 122, 112, 14
        })
    }, {
        new g("libjaggl.jnilib", "jaggl_2_0_771403788.lib", new String[] {
            "Loading 3D library", "Lade 3D-Softwarebibliothek", "Chargement de la librairie 3D", "Carregando biblioteca 3D", "Loading 3D library"
        }, 0x139ec, 18197, new int[] {
            84, 56, 27, 69, -37, -80, -16, -10, -3, -71, 
            -73, -106, -83, 66, 73, -126, 97, -103, -28, -11
        })
    }, {
        new g("libjaggl.jnilib", "jaggl_3_0_-1375336825.lib", new String[] {
            "Loading 3D library", "Lade 3D-Softwarebibliothek", "Chargement de la librairie 3D", "Carregando biblioteca 3D", "Loading 3D library"
        }, 0x279ec, 35096, new int[] {
            94, 75, -21, 49, -83, 82, -7, 20, -55, -43, 
            -107, 66, -86, -90, -118, 21, -78, 97, -47, -17
        })
    }, {
        new g("jaggl.dll", "jaggl_4_0_-717742460.lib", new String[] {
            "Loading 3D library", "Lade 3D-Softwarebibliothek", "Chargement de la librairie 3D", "Carregando biblioteca 3D", "Loading 3D library"
        }, 0x17000, 40526, new int[] {
            9, 72, 72, 126, 45, 23, 101, -54, -84, 105, 
            -41, -58, 117, 74, -29, 93, 122, -56, -115, 85
        })
    }
};
public static g e[] = {
    new g("jagmisc.dll", "jagmisc_0_-1116511889.lib", new String[] {
        "Loading utility library", "Lade Utility-Softwarebibliothek", "Chargement de la librairie utilitaire", "Carregando biblioteca de ferramentas", "Loading utility library"
    }, 49152, 24425, new int[] {
        56, -117, -76, 64, -93, -75, -91, 17, -117, 20, 
        -61, -38, -57, -69, -68, 0, -94, 87, -125, 40
    }), new g("jagmiscms.dll", "jagmisc_1_-384383368.lib", new String[] {
        "Loading utility library", "Lade Utility-Softwarebibliothek", "Chargement de la librairie utilitaire", "Carregando biblioteca de ferramentas", "Loading utility library"
    }, 49152, 24859, new int[] {
        114, 91, -1, -2, -85, 32, -83, -48, -51, 60, 
        74, -1, 112, -75, 55, 80, -124, -44, -118, -72
    }), new g("jagmisc64.dll", "jagmisc_2_954087334.lib", new String[] {
        "Loading utility library", "Lade Utility-Softwarebibliothek", "Chargement de la librairie utilitaire", "Carregando biblioteca de ferramentas", "Loading utility library"
    }, 58880, 29373, new int[] {
        -2, 6, -23, 7, -65, -105, 98, -83, -34, -99, 
        -76, -116, -63, -80, 18, -12, -1, 22, -79, 0
    })
};
public static int f[] = {
    0x8c1111, 0xffffff
};
public static String g[] = {
    "runescape", "stellardawn"
};
public static int h[] = {
    0xffffff, 0xffffff
};

}[/code]

you could simply cache the int[] field values as they are the sha digest of the files, when the loader changes you can then check which files have changed (probably all of them)

Read full topic

item.title: RS2 Updater
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Killer-99-pkz:

Please point out things that you think is rong with my code…

I haven’t looked at the actual code either, but I’ve already said a few areas in which it could be improved. The only way to tell if jagex has released a new file (not new version, new file) is to download it and see if it is the same, a hash does this well, in java you could use crc32 or something. Also, check every X amount of time (like I said, I check every hour). And add the ability to add more files to the check and such.

Read full topic

item.title: RS2 Updater
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

NEW INVOKESPECIAL DUP LDC "Hello" INVOKEVIRTUAL DUP LDC " " INVOKEVIRTUAL DUP LDC "world" INVOKEVIRTUAL INVOKEVIRTUAL toString()
v.

LDC "Hello world"

12 instructions v. 1. /pedantic

That said: he seems to know a bit of java but he doesn’t actually know about the proper design of a java based application.

That doesn’t mean optimize it. It means asking questions: is this piece of code going to hog my bandwidth and if so is it still useful. If you can solve the first question you have a greater number of people who will actually be able to use your code. If you don’t solve the second then no one will use your code.

Just think about the effects of it. Once you actually know how to write it properly, we’ll teach you how to write it neatly and then we’ll finally teach you how to optimize it. Of course that will probably be in the form of ridicule but you should focus on the first bit first.

Read full topic

item.title: RS2 Updater
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

When a special-ed kid draws a self portrait that looks more like a bicycle it is sweet and somewhat endearing. Anyone with even the slightest amount of compassion can look at the drawing with the perspective that the artist tried the best that he or she could and such determination should be admired and even emulated by those more gifted.

When a child presents his mom or dad with a gift that was obviously hand-made, his or her parents appreciate the effort and though that was put into the gift. It really doesn’t matter that the gift wasn’t temporally of great worth; it is of intrinsic worth.

I am going to have to take a chance and wager a guess that you might not be a retard. Furthermore you are sure as hell not one of my children. Your offerings would be far better received if you were less of a jackass. It takes years of pontification to achieve the level of elitist jerkism that many of us enjoy.

All joking aside, for the love of god before you release anything to the public make sure it adds value. I am notorious for releasing very little to anyone. I keep everything to myself and an ultra elitist group of folks. Your arguments about optimization and performance are laughable. At first I thought you were putting on a parody of the narcissistic people that see x * 2 and cry “NEWB” because the person didn’t optimize it to x << 1 but I was mistaken, you are serious. Nevermind the fact that the person has actually implemented something elegant. One of the first rules of performance tuning is to first finish the implementation before attempting to optimize. If all you have is System.out.println(“hello” + " " + “world”); does it really fkn matter that it results in a few more jvm instructions? Hell, if you even knew what BigO even meant I would be surprised. O(1) = O(1)… in the scheme of things it may help… but the amount of time wasted bitching about it isn’t worth the 3 instructions saved processing the stupid executable…

The point that I’m trying to make is this: the only thing worse than someone that doesn’t know anything is someone that doesn’t realize that they don’t know anything.

@BAsh: O(1) = O(1)…

Incidentally most compilers (mine included) optimized that code to:

0 getstatic #2 <java/lang/System.out>
3 ldc #3 <Hello world>
5 invokevirtual #4 <java/io/PrintStream.println>

Read full topic

item.title: RS2 Updater
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Killer-99-pkz:

yes but yours uses up tons of bandwidth no matter if they update it or not, i would just load the html files for the game, play.ws?m=1 then the loader file ends with a ZIP CRC32 which you can parse from it and just check your currents sums and same with the client. if the file doesent have a sum attached then just download it regardless and check your md5

Again, they could change the actual file and not change it’s name right? The only way to actually check if the file is the same is to download it and check.

Read full topic

item.title: RS2 Updater
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“Killer-99-pkz, post:12, topic:299689”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=395982.msg2941754#msg2941754 date=1251929878]
My script is set up to run hourly with cron, takes up no memory when it doesn’t run, and doesn’t constantly poll an update server.

If you want to run it on windows, just install cygwin and run it.

There is absolutely no point to this. Along with that, it is missing runescape.js5, and runescape_gl.js5. Please fix.

I just updated mine to get these.
[/quote]
this polls every 30 minutes, yours has a bad version checking logic, all they have to do is change the error system and that varible wont be there[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 02, 2009, 04:23:17 pm[/size][hr][quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=395982.msg2941756#msg2941756 date=1251930041]

My script is set up to run hourly with cron, takes up no memory when it doesn’t run, and doesn’t constantly poll an update server.

If you want to run it on windows, just install cygwin and run it.

There is absolutely no point to this. Along with that, it is missing runescape.js5, and runescape_gl.js5. Please fix.

I just updated mine to get these.

Too bad you don’t know how to unpack them. Wooohooooooo
[/quote]

its probably in the loader or client…[/quote]

First of all, that has nothing to do with error system. The client version is passed to the start-game method, and therefore has to be pushed some how. His code searches for it. Although, I do admit, I like my method better. Look for the p4 invoke and look at arguments. The one that isn’t consistent among previous p4 invokes is the client version. The p4 invoke is inside the update server connection code.

Secondly, it is in neither. [br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 02, 2009, 10:28:20 pm[/size][hr]BTW mopar, the format is pretty simple. I’ll work on an unpacker and I’ll show you then

Read full topic

item.title: RS2 Updater
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Killer-99-pkz, post:12, topic:299689”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=395982.msg2941754#msg2941754 date=1251929878]
My script is set up to run hourly with cron, takes up no memory when it doesn’t run, and doesn’t constantly poll an update server.

If you want to run it on windows, just install cygwin and run it.

There is absolutely no point to this. Along with that, it is missing runescape.js5, and runescape_gl.js5. Please fix.

I just updated mine to get these.
[/quote]
this polls every 30 minutes, yours has a bad version checking logic, all they have to do is change the error system and that varible wont be there[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 02, 2009, 04:23:17 pm[/size][hr][quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=395982.msg2941756#msg2941756 date=1251930041]

My script is set up to run hourly with cron, takes up no memory when it doesn’t run, and doesn’t constantly poll an update server.

If you want to run it on windows, just install cygwin and run it.

There is absolutely no point to this. Along with that, it is missing runescape.js5, and runescape_gl.js5. Please fix.

I just updated mine to get these.

Too bad you don’t know how to unpack them. Wooohooooooo
[/quote]

its probably in the loader or client…[/quote]

And all they have to do is update the client without changing the version number and you won’t get the new client. Mine gets the new client no matter what, because it relies on the md5sum of the client instead of the version.

[quote=“oksuper_, post:11, topic:299689”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=395982.msg2941754#msg2941754 date=1251929878]
My script is set up to run hourly with cron, takes up no memory when it doesn’t run, and doesn’t constantly poll an update server.

If you want to run it on windows, just install cygwin and run it.

There is absolutely no point to this. Along with that, it is missing runescape.js5, and runescape_gl.js5. Please fix.

I just updated mine to get these.
[/quote]
Too bad you don’t know how to unpack them. Wooohooooooo[/quote]

Never looked into it, care to share?

Read full topic
